title: Order Exceptions
content:
• Home
  • ››Manhattan Active® Supply Chain Planning
  • ››Process & Configuration Guides
  • ››Order Build
  • ››Order Exceptions

Order Exceptions

Previous I Next
  • Overview
  • Process Flow
    • How to set up Order Exception Policy
  • Link Exception Policy to Sourcing Relationship
  • Clear Exceptions
  • Related Articles

Overview

Order exceptions refer to situations where the system encounters issues or discrepancies that prevent it from processing an order in the usual manner for various reasons. Order Exceptions identify order lines and order conditions that might require the buyers' attention.  These exceptions can arise due to various reasons, such as Order Total is High, Order Total is Low, Extra days configured is above the threshold. Buyers may need to review the order with an exception before approving the order.

 

There are two type of Exceptions:-

  • Header Exceptions: These exceptions apply to the entire order, impacting the overall processing or fulfillment of the order.

    • Order Total High

    • Order Total Low

  • Line Exceptions: Line exceptions, on the other hand, apply to specific lines or items within an order.

    • Backorder

    • CommQtyBackorder

    • CommQtyCCO

    • CommQtyHoldout

    • CommQtyOnReserve

    • DaysSupply

    • Extra Days Warning

    • FrozenSOQ

    • HasLifeCycleCode

    • IncompleteOrderTotal

    • InsufficientOnHandDay

    • InsufficientSOQ

    • Line Total High

    • LineTotalLow

    • ManualSOQ

    • OrderNotWithinActiveBracket

    • OrderTotalHigh

    • OrderTotalLow

    • ServiceLevelCheckNotEqualToA

    • ServiceLevelCheckEqualToA

    • SKUWithLeadTimeOverride

 

The order exceptions can be set at a relationship level. 

 

 

Process Flow

 

 

  • Set up Order Exception Policy: Refer How to set up Order Exception Policy for more details
  • Link the Exception Policy with the sourcing Relationship. (Refer How to link Sourcing Relationship)
    • Once the exception policy is configured, the same has to be linked with the sourcing relationship. 
    • Each sourcing relationship can have a different policy.

Example

  • In the below example,
    • Order Policy 1 is set up for Vendor1→DC1
    • Order Policy 2 is set up for Vendor2→DC1
    • Order Policy 3 is set up for Vendor3→DC1
  • Vendor1 might be a regular vendor and the buyer wants to see an exception only if the order quantity goes above 1000 units.
  • Vendor2 might be the second choice and the buyer wants to be alerted when the Order level crosses 500 units
  • Vendor3 might be the last choice and the buyer wants to be alerted when the Order level crosses 100 units
Vendor DC Order Exception Policy Exception Type Threshold
Vendor1 DC1 Order Policy 1 Order Total High 1000
Vendor2 DC1 Order Policy 2 Order Total High 500
Vendor3 DC1 Order Policy 3 Order Total High 100

  • Evaluate Order Exceptions
    • Once the Exception Policy is created and is linked to the Sourcing Relationship, each time an order is calculated, the system evaluates if there are any exceptions at the Sourcing Relationship Level. The system looks for exceptions in the below scenarios:-
      • Order Build
      • SOQ Computation/Recalculate

Example

 

Exceptions will be generated if the set threshold is crossed. There are also exception types which do not require a threshold, which means there will be an exception on the order even if there isn't a threshold value.

 

Vendor DC Item Order Exception Policy Exception Type Threshold Extra Days SOQ Exceptions
Vendor1  DC1   Order Policy 1 Order Total High 1000   1210 Yes (Header Exception)
Vendor1 DC1 Item1 Order Policy 1 Line Total High 500   750 Yes (Line Level Exception)
Vendor1 DC1 Item2 Order Policy 1 Line Total High 300   380 Yes (Line Level Exception)
Vendor1 DC1 Item3 Order Policy 1 Line Total Low 100   80 Yes (Line Level Exception)
Vendor2 DC1   Order Policy 2 Order Total Low 500   380 Yes (Header Exception)
Vendor2 DC1 Item1 Order Policy 2 Extra Days 2 5 280 Yes (Line Level Exception)
Vendor2 DC1 Item1 Order Policy 2 Insufficient SOQ     100 Yes (Line Level Exception)

 

In the above example, 

  • Order Level Exceptions
    • These exceptions apply to the entire order.  
      • Vendor1→DC1 - Order Total High - 1 (The SOQ for Vendor1→DC1 relationship is 1210 units, and the threshold is 1000 units. Hence, we see an Order Total High Exception at the order level)
      • Vendor1→DC1 - Order Total Low - 1 (The SOQ for Vendor2→DC1 relationship is 400 units, and the threshold is 500 units. Hence, we see an Order Total Low Exception at the order level)
  • Order Line Level Exceptions
    • Line exceptions, on the other hand, apply to specific lines or items within an order.
      • Vendor1→DC1 - Line Total High-2 (Item1,Item2), Line Total Low-1 (Item3)
      • Vendor2→DC1 - Extra Days 1(Item1), Insufficient SOQ-1 (Item1)

  • Review/Clear Exceptions (Refer Clear Exceptions)
    • Exceptions, if any, will be displayed on the Suggested Orders UI. This gives a chance for the users to view the exceptions and take appropriate actions.
    • Users can clear exceptions by the below methods:-
      • Clear Exceptions (without any corrections)
      • Review Exceptions and adjust the exception values
      • Approve the Order (Automatically clears exceptions)

Configuration

How to set up Order Exception Policy

  • Admins can configure the Exception Policy can be configured on the UI(Order Exception Policy from Menu) and using the API.
  • Multiple Exception types can be configured within a single Policy
  • Here is the list of System Order Exception types that can be configured.

    • Exception Types

       

      Backorder
      CommQtyBackorder
      CommQtyCCO
      CommQtyHoldout
      CommQtyOnReserve
      DaysSupply
      ExtraDaysWarning
      FrozenSOQ
      HasLifeCycleCode
      IncompleteOrderTotals
      InsufficientOnHandDays
      InsufficientSOQ
      LineTotalHigh
      LineTotalLow
      ManualSOQ
      OrderNotWithinActiveBracket  (Order Level Exception)
      OrderTotalHigh (Order Level Exception)
      OrderTotalLow  (Order Level Exception)
      ServiceLevelCheckNotEqualToA
      ServiceLevelCheckEqualToA
      SKUWithLeadTimeOverride
      UnusualForecastChange
      UnusualHighDemand
      UnusualLowDemand
  • There is no option of creating a custom exception type for now.

POST - {{url}}/ai-inventoryoptimization/api/ai-inventoryoptimization/orderExceptionPolicy/save

 

{

"OrderException": [

{

"CreateWhenSOQIsZero": true,

"Description": "OrderException",

"LifeCycleStatusId": "ACTIVE",

"OrderExceptionId": "Order Total High",

"OrderExceptionType": {

"OrderExceptionTypeId": "OrderTotalHigh"

},

"Threshold": 100,

"ThresholdUOM": "EA"

},

{

"CreateWhenSOQIsZero": true,

"Description": "OrderException",

"LifeCycleStatusId": "ACTIVE",

"OrderExceptionId": "Extra Days Warning",

"OrderExceptionType": {

"OrderExceptionTypeId": "ExtraDaysWarning"

},

"Threshold": 2,

"ThresholdUOM": "EA"

},

{

"CreateWhenSOQIsZero": true,

"Description": "OrderException",

"LifeCycleStatusId": "ACTIVE",

"OrderExceptionId": "Line Total High",

"OrderExceptionType": {

"OrderExceptionTypeId": "LineTotalHigh"

},

"Threshold": 70,

"ThresholdUOM": "EA"

}

],

"OrderExceptionPolicyId": "OrderException"

}

 

Link Exception Policy to Sourcing Relationship

  • Exception Policies can be linked to Sourcing Relationship from the UI or using the API

POST - {{url}}/itemlocation/api/itemlocation/sourcingRelationship/save

 

{

"SourceLocationId": "DC1",

"LocationId": "Store1",

"DefaultTransitTime": "7.0",

"OrderCycle": "7",

"RelationType": {

"RelationTypeId": "Regular"

},

"OrderExceptionPolicyId": "OrderException"

}

 

Clear Exceptions

 

POST - {{url}}/ai-inventoryoptimization/api/ai-inventoryoptimization/suggestedOrderLine/clearException

 

[

    {

        "SourceLocationId": "DC1",

        "LocationId": "Store1",

        "ItemId": ""

    }

]
